title: Chromatin-dependent motif syntax defines differentiation trajectories.
abstract_text: Transcription factors (TFs) recognizing DNA motifs within regulatory regions drive cell identity. Despite recent advances, their specificity remains incompletely understood. Here, we address this by contrasting two TFs, Neurogenin-2 (NGN2) and MyoD1, which recognize ubiquitous E-box motifs yet drive distinct cell fates toward neurons and muscles, respectively. Upon induction in mouse embryonic stem cells, we monitor binding across differentiation, employing an interpretable machine learning approach that integrates preexisting DNA accessibility. This reveals a chromatin-dependent motif syntax, delineating both common and factor-specific binding, validated by cellular and in vitro assays. Shared binding sites reside in open chromatin, locally influenced by nucleosomes. In contrast, factor-specific binding in closed chromatin involves NGN2 and MyoD1 acting as pioneer factors, influenced by motif variant frequencies, motif spacing, and interaction partners, which together account for subsequent lineage divergence. Transferring our methodology to other models demonstrates how a combination of opportunistic binding and context-specific chromatin-opening underpin TF specificity, driving differentiation trajectories.

Summary Transcription factors (TFs) recognizing DNA motifs within regulatory regions drive cell identity. Despite recent advances, their specificity remains incompletely understood. Here, we address this by contrasting two TFs, Neurogenin-2 (NGN2) and MyoD1, which recognize ubiquitous E-box motifs yet drive distinct cell fates toward neurons and muscles, respectively. Upon induction in mouse embryonic stem cells, we monitor binding across differentiation, employing an interpretable machine learning approach that integrates preexisting DNA accessibility. This reveals a chromatin-dependent motif syntax, delineating both common and factor-specific binding, validated by cellular and in vitro assays. Shared binding sites reside in open chromatin, locally influenced by nucleosomes. In contrast, factor-specific binding in closed chromatin involves NGN2 and MyoD1 acting as pioneer factors, influenced by motif variant frequencies, motif spacing, and interaction partners, which together account for subsequent lineage divergence. Transferring our methodology to other models demonstrates how a combination of opportunistic binding and context-specific chromatin-opening underpin TF specificity, driving differentiation trajectories. Graphical abstract Highlights • Chromatin context and motif grammar guide specific TF binding among many sites • Chromatin-dependent motif rules explain opportunistic, cooperative, and pioneer binding • Subtle motif variants direct gene activation via distinct TF complexes • Predictive models generalize across TFs and differentiation systems Durdu et al. crack the code of transcription-factor specificity by integrating chromatin context and motif syntax, validated by targeted assays. Focusing on NGN2 and MyoD1, they develop predictive models, distinguish functional binding from millions of potentials, and uncover generalizable rules explaining how transcription factors drive distinct cell fates. Keywords transcription factor specificity motif syntax motif variants pioneer factors chromatin accessibility gene regulation cell differentiation machine learning predictive models E-box Published: August 7, 2025 Introduction Eukaryotic transcription factors (TFs) play an important role in creating cell-type diversity in multicellular organisms, mediating selective activation of genomic regions. Unlike their prokaryotic counterparts, most eukaryotic TFs typically bind to DNA sequence motifs that are low in information content due to being short and degenerate, set against the backdrop of a vast genome. 1 This presents a paradox: among the millions of potential TF-binding sites, only a few thousand are occupied. This indicates that the presence of a cognate-motif is not a reliable predictor of eukaryotic TF binding. Yet, TFs, even when recognizing short and highly similar cognate motifs, interact with the genome with high precision and direct diverse cellular outcomes. This is exemplified by the basic-helix-loop-helix (bHLH) TF family with over 100 members that dimerize through bHLH domains and bind to the CANNTG motif known as E-box, occurring more than ten million times in mammalian genomes. Despite the low information content of the motif, the bHLH TFs drive distinct cellular differentiation programs, such as neurogenesis by Neurogenin2 (NGN2) or myogenesis by Myoblast determination protein 1 (MyoD1). 2 , 3 , 4 The DNA-binding preferences of bHLH TFs were shown to be insufficient to explain the selected bound sites among the many potential ones 5 nor the differences in binding patterns between them. 6 While it is generally assumed that chromatin provides a barrier that masks the millions of sites, it remains largely unclear, what determines specificity in binding to individual loci. 7 , 8 If these abundant motifs are all masked by chromatin, how could such opportunistic, open-chromatin-dependent binding activate the correct set of silent genes, required to drive new cell fates? Specific TF-binding patterns are prevalently described as “context-dependent,” shaped by two main mechanisms: direct recruitment via protein-protein interactions and indirect recruitment through chromatin made permissive by other TFs. 9 While direct interactions can promote combinatorial TF assembly at loci, they explain only small fraction of TF localization, partly due to the large distances between co-occurring motifs. 10 The second model proposes that “pioneer” or “chromatin-insensitive” factors, capable of binding nucleosomes, remodel chromatin and facilitate access for other TFs, thereby influencing their targeting in a cell-type-specific manner. Despite their ability to open or modify some target sites, these factors do not consistently bind to same sites across cell types, nor do they occupy all sites with their cognate motifs. 11 , 12 , 13 , 14 This variability underscores a context-dependence that remains poorly understood, highlighting a significant gap in our understanding of genomic targeting. 7 To investigate the mechanisms underlying TF targeting, model systems enabling controlled modulation of TF activity and monitoring of binding relative to the chromatin state prior to TF presence are needed. Although lineage-specifying TFs have been studied in dynamic contexts, such as developing embryos, 15 the complexity and heterogeneity of these systems limits precise control over TF timing and chromatin state assessment. Since TF binding both affects and is influenced by chromatin, temporal resolution in modulating TF activity is critical. Acknowledging this, several studies have implemented induced TF expression and explored the concepts of TF-binding preferences, pioneering and chromatin-opening activity, albeit at later states of cellular transition. 6 , 16 , 17 , 18 , 19 To gain further insights, we established homogeneous differentiation models in mouse embryonic stem cells (mESCs) through controlled induction of two bHLH TFs, NGN2 and MyoD1, driving generation of neurons and myocytes, respectively. This system enabled time-resolved analysis of genomic binding and downstream responses of two similar short-motif-recognizing TFs in relation to DNA sequence and chromatin state. By measuring their immediate genomic binding in a similar cellular state, we identified key determinants of chromatin engagement that shape their specific binding patterns among millions of potential sites. Using machine learning, we uncovered a chromatin-dependent motif syntax with strong predictive power underlined by preexisting DNA accessibility, motif variants, motif frequency, and relative positioning. NGN2 and MyoD1 open chromatin depending on single base-pair (bp) differences in their motifs, with patterns that can differ from their binding strength. Cellular and in vitro assays show that these motif variants engage differentially with other TFs and the dimerization partners of NGN2 and MyoD1. These specific activities of NGN2 and MyoD1 drive expression of distinct downstream TFs, which further alter chromatin accessibility and influence subsequent binding. Together, these findings demonstrate how short-motif-binding TFs regulate chromatin with predictable specificity, governed by a generalizable motif syntax. This syntax accounts for both, rare pioneering and frequent chromatin-sensitive binding as well as cooperative regulation at factor-specific and shared target sites. Results Controlled induction of NGN2 and MyoD1 in mESCs drives reproducible and synchronous differentiation To address how TFs with highly abundant and similar sequence motifs can distinctly guide specific lineages, we established a system in mESCs, allowing for the controlled induction of individual TFs. Specifically, we employed NGN2, which directs mESCs toward a neuronal lineage ( Figures S1 A–S1D), and contrasted it with MyoD1, one of the earliest identified lineage-driving TFs known to induce myocyte formation 20 , 21 , 22 ( Figure 1 A). Both factors employ bHLH domains for DNA binding and recognize highly similar motifs. Figure 1 NGN2 and MyoD1 induces neurogenesis and myogenesis, respectively, when expressed in mESCs despite recognizing similar short DNA sequence motifs (A) Immunofluorescence images of mESCs prior and 2-days post-induction of NGN2 and MyoD1, resulting in distinct cell types. Nuclear marker Hoechst in magenta, neuronal marker TubIII, and myocyte marker α-actinin in green. Scale bar, 20 μm. The logos represent the E-box motif, de novo identified by HOMER, considering the 500 most enriched ChIP-seq peaks ( Figures S2 A and S2B). (B) Differentiation trajectories illustrated by principal-component analysis (PCA) of the transcriptomes for mESCs (blue), NGN2 (green), MyoD1 (purple), and noTF (gray) control induction. (C) Genome browser tracks of the Dll1 gene locus with E-box motifs (black bars) illustrating shared and factor-specific binding by NGN2 and MyoD1 at 6 h. For controlled induction, we engineered mESCs with the Tet-On system with single-locus insertion of the respective TFs ( STAR Methods 23 ). GFP expression alone, without an additional TF expression (noTF), served as control ( Figures S1 E–S1I). Upon NGN2 and MyoD1 induction, mESCs underwent synchronous differentiation into neurons or myocytes within less than 3 days, as documented by time-lapse imaging. Within 2 days post-induction, cell division ceased, and the characteristic cell-type-specific features were detected ( Figures 1 A, S1 H, and S1J; Video S1 ). 24 , 25 Transcriptome analysis similarly revealed distinct gene-expression trajectories, aligned with bona fide myogenic or neuronal differentiation ( Figures 1 B and S1 K–S1M). Using this controlled system, we next examined the initial genomic binding of NGN2 and MyoD1 ( Figures 1 C and S1 N). Video S1. Time-lapse imaging of mESCs differentiating into neurons and myocytes upon NGN2 and MyoD1 induction in contrast to mESCs without TF induction, related to Figure 1 Genomic engagement is a function of prior accessibility, motif frequency, and motif sequence To investigate genome-wide binding following induction, we profiled NGN2 using chromatin immunoprecipitation sequencing (ChIP-seq) at 6 h after induction ( Figure 1 C), as the earliest time point where NGN2 is detected in most cells. A DNA-binding mutant form of NGN2 (NGN2mut) and GFP alone served as controls ( Figures S1 G and S2 A). Combining multiple independent replicates identified ∼14,000 consensus peaks as sites of NGN2’s initial chromatin engagement, including expected targets such as Neurod1 ( Figures S2 A and S2C). Among these, the typical E-box motif was highly enriched, with specific bp preferences, especially in the central nucleotides such as GA, GC, TA, and GG ( Figure S2 E; STAR Methods 26 , 27 ). Notably, 95% of peaks harbored an exact matching sequence to one of these motifs. Similarly, profiling MyoD1 identified ∼13,000 bound consensus sites, enriched for E-box motifs with GC, GG, GA, and AC central nucleotides ( Figures S2 B, S2D, and S2F). The presence of these cognate-motif sequences alone, despite their high enrichment, does not account for specific binding patterns of NGN2 or MyoD1 as there are over a million NGN2 cognate motifs in the genome, leaving 99% unbound. We hypothesized that NGN2 and MyoD1 might preferentially bind sites within open chromatin. To explore this, we contrasted binding with genome-wide DNA accessibility prior to TF induction using DNase I hypersensitivity (DHS) mapping 28 ( Figures 2 A and 2B). This revealed that motifs residing in open chromatin, as defined by high DHS signal, are indeed more likely to be bound than those residing in closed chromatin. For NGN2, 61% of motifs in most accessible chromatin whereas only 0.4% in closed chromatin will be bound ( Figure 2 C). A similar pattern emerged for MyoD1: ranging from 0.2% in closed to 54% in highly accessible chromatin ( Figure 2 D). These findings suggest that preexisting chromatin accessibility is a key determinant in whether NGN2 and MyoD1 are likely to engage with their cognate motifs. While binding to closed chromatin is relatively rare, there are a large number of motifs residing in closed chromatin. In turn, they generate one third of all bound sites ( Figure 2 A). Comparative analysis of binding at these cognate motifs revealed that less accessible but bound sites tend to contain multiple cognate motifs in proximity, which is rarely observed for unbound sites ( Figures 2 E and 2F). This suggests that the presence of multiple motifs increases the likelihood of engaging closed chromatin, conceivably by enhancing binding strength to a genomic sequence. Figure 2 DNA accessibility and cognate-motif occurrences are major factors underlying initial binding patterns (A) Density plot showing preexisting DNase-seq (DHS 0 h) and 6 h post-induction NGN2 ChIP-seq enrichments in all 1.3 million NGN2-motif-containing genomic regions (500 bp with minimum one non-overlapping cognate-motif, described in Figure S2 E). Percentage of total sites in each quarter indicates that the majority of cognate motifs reside in closed chromatin and will not be bound by NGN2 upon induction, yet the heterochromatic but bound regions make up one third of all NGN2 binding. (B) Example cognate-motif sites for open-bound, closed-bound, open-unbound, and closed-unbound categories are visualized as genomic tracks of 0 h DNase-seq, NGN2 motifs, 6 h NGN2 ChIP-seq, and control GFP ChIP-seq. (C and D) Percentage of bound cognate-motif sites (enrichment > 1.5) grouped in bins according to their accessibility prior to induction, showing higher likelihood of binding (>50%) in open regions and low likelihood (<1%) in closed regions, indicating the impact of DNA accessibility. (E and F) Frequency of multiple motifs (gray: one, light-blue: two, and dark-blue: three or more cognate motifs) in consensus ChIP-seq peaks and rest of the cognate-motif sites in the genome, grouped in bins according to their accessibility prior to induction (e.g., accessibility < 6), showing closed-bound sites contain more multi-motifs. (G and H) Fitted line plots of average ChIP-seq enrichment versus DHS 0 h at single cognate-motif sites (residing in consensus ChIP-seq peaks and their matched backgrounds), grouped by the frequent central nucleotides of their E-box cognate motifs. The separation in the curves of motif variants at a given accessibility illustrates the difference in the likelihood to be bound. (I) Heatmap of combined NGN2 and MyoD1 peaks, split in three groups: strongly bound by both factors (N and M), exclusively bound by one factor (N or M), and preferentially bound by one of the two (N > M or M > N), visualizing DHS 0 h (red), NGN2 ChIP-seq (green), MyoD1 ChIP-seq (purple), and cognate-motif variants with TA, GA, GC, and GG central nucleotides (black). (J) Genomic regions with exclusive or overlapping NGN2 and MyoD1 binding, exemplifying the effect of chromatin accessibility and occurrence of cognate-motif variants (green: NGN2-preferred, pruple:MyoD1-preferred) present at the peak centers. Next, we asked whether the likelihood of binding relates to particular motif variants. To test this, we analyzed NGN2 and MyoD1 binding at genomic regions with single motif occurrences relative to initial DNA accessibility. While all motif variants, grouped by their central nucleotides, were comparably bound when residing in accessible chromatin, differences became apparent in less-accessible chromatin ( Figures 2 G and 2H). This reflects NGN2’s binding potential to E-box motif variants, ranked from highest to lowest, as TA, GA, GC, and GG variants ( Figures 2 G, S2 G, and S2H ) . Similarly, MyoD1 showed comparable binding in open chromatin and a strong preference for GG and GC variants in closed chromatin ( Figure 2 H). These data suggest that motif variants appear less critical for open chromatin, but important for engaging closed chromatin. We next addressed if other preexisting chromatin features, such as histone modifications, might predict binding. 12 , 29 Contrasting well-characterized histone marks revealed that modifications that are hallmarks of open chromatin such as H3K4 methylation indeed correlate with binding. Importantly, however, none of them contributed additional predictive information beyond that already provided by DHS ( Figures S2 I and S2J). This suggests that in the case of NGN2 and MyoD1, individual histone marks themselves are unlikely to account for global motif engagement independent of DNA accessibility. If genomic binding of NGN2/MyoD1 depend on motif occurrence and DNA accessibility, then differential binding should occur in genomic sites that are initially closed but have higher frequency of NGN2’s and MyoD1’s individually preferred motifs. Conversely, similar binding should occur in regions with higher accessibility, or where different preferred motifs are adjacent to each other and thus bound by both. Contrasting bound regions among NGN2- and MyoD1-binding sites indeed illustrates a general overlap at highly accessible regions and distinct binding at sites with lower accessibility, which are enriched for factor-specific motif variants ( Figures 2 I and S2 K). These binding patterns can be observed at individual loci as illustrated by a NGN2 specific low accessible region with multiple GA motifs (E-box motifs with GA central nucleotides) or a MyoD1-specific low accessible region, containing one GG and two GC motifs. In contrast, a single GC motif residing in accessible chromatin is bound by both factors ( Figures 2 J and S2 L). These observations support a model in which chromatin accessibility explains both overlapping and differential binding patterns between two lineage-driving TFs ( Figure S2 M). Although our analysis thus far identifies contributors to the distinct binding of NGN2 versus MyoD1, these components alone still fail to account for many genomic binding events, including those unbound motifs residing in accessible regions or with multiple motifs in proximity ( Figures 2 B–2F). This suggests the presence of additional features that our analysis has not captured. This motivated us to adopt a de novo integrative feature learning approach aimed at generating a model, leveraging both previously identified and potentially additional features to predict binding. CNNs identify a chromatin-dependent motif syntax that underlies TF binding Deep learning models, combined with interpretation tools, offer the most informative means of identifying de novo cis -regulatory sequence rules through combinatorial representations. 30 , 31 , 32 , 33 , 34 , 35 , 36 , 37 , 38 To gain insights into the features that determine primary TF-binding specificity, we utilized a deep learning approach. Specifically, we built a convolutional neural network (CNN) model that takes as input DNA sequence, combined with preexisting chromatin accessibility ( Figure 3 A; STAR Methods 30 , 39 ). Training this CNN model with NGN2 and MyoD1 ChIP-seq enrichments predicted the degree of binding remarkably well, with the correlation between prediction and experimental data being comparable to that between experimental replicates ( Figures S2 C, S2D, S3 A, and S3B). Figure 3 Identification of a chromatin-dependent motif syntax using a CNN (A) Scheme of the applied CNN for predicting the primary 6 h binding of NGN2 and MyoD1, using DNA sequence and continuous 0 h DHS (DNase I) signal as input. (B) Contrasting frequency-based motif representation (PFM), informing about the frequency of the DNA bases in the enriched motifs versus contribution weight matrices (CWM), identified by the CNN model, and informing about the contribution of the DNA bases to the degree of binding enrichments. DNA sequences are represented with the letters A, C, G, T, and accessibility with the letter D. Differences in PFM and CWM highlight the binding strength contribution of flanking nucleotides and less frequent central nucleotides. The “D” profile indicates high contribution of accessibility directly overlapping with the E-box motif and lower contribution of the surrounding. ( n = 26,128 E-box instances for NGN2 and 25,327 for MyoD1). (C) Calculation of NGN2 and MyoD1’s relative affinities to E-box motif variants independent of the genomic sequence context at any given accessibility using the CNN model on synthetic sequences (average gained binding strength upon placing the same motif across various backgrounds with simulated accessibility). The predicted binding strengths across different 0 h accessibility are represented from blue to red. (D) Single-locus display of DNA sequence, 0 h accessibility profile and their deconvolved contribution scores for NGN2 6 h binding prediction, reporting on the features accounting for the binding strength. (E) Predicted NGN2 binding strength contribution of the flanking bases (5′-flanking in red, 3′ in green) for CAGATG motif. (F) Contribution of the flanking bases to the binding prediction of E-box motif variants (central nucleotides in blue, 3′-flanking nucleotides in green). (G) Comparison of pre-induction (0 h) MNase and DNase I digestion profiles at NGN2 cognate-motif sites residing in open chromatin, grouped as sites that will be bound or not bound by NGN2 upon 6 h induction. (H) DNA sequence motif (seqlet, identified by TF-MoDISco), containing two E-box motifs, that is informative for NGN2 binding prediction at bound sites residing in closed chromatin. (I) Fraction of NGN2 bound-closed sites with two NGN2 motifs at various base pair distances between motif centers. Inner: modeled NGN2 binding (AlphaFold3) on two 11-bp apart (highest binding potential) NGN2 motifs. To identify features influencing TF-binding predictions, 40 we utilized DeepLIFT 26 and quantified the contribution scores of the DNA sequences and chromatin accessibility. Consistent with previous analysis, extracting DNA sequence motifs using TF-MoDISco 41 identified E-box motifs as major DNA sequence component for the prediction, as well as other known interacting TF motifs, such as that for PBX or MyoD1 ( Figures 3 B and S3 C). 6 , 42 In addition to motif sequences, the model identified local accessibility as a significant contributor to binding. This should enable further use of the CNN model to estimate the chromatin-binding strengths for individual E-box motif sequences isolated from the genomic sequence context. To do so, we averaged the predicted TF binding on E-box motifs embedded in hundreds of in-silico -generated background sequences ( STAR Methods 37 ) at varying initial accessibilities ( Figures 3 C and S3 D). This is exemplified by the calculations on the motif variants with only few isolated binding instances, such as CATATG and CAACTG for NGN2 and MyoD1, respectively ( Figures 3 B and 3C). Here, the model estimates the likelihood of TF binding to a given DNA sequence as a function of its initial accessibility, which is in line with the variant binding preferences identified above ( Figures 2 G and 2H). Visual inspection of genomic tracks of contribution scores calculated for DNA sequence and accessibility illustrates that the CNN model assigns different degrees of importance to E-box motifs depending on sequence variations and their local accessibility ( Figures 3 D and S3 E). Identified sequence variations were not limited to the motif itself but also included flanking bases that, in several cases, appear to be more relevant for binding than the central bases. Calculating the binding strengths revealed that even a single flanking base change can impact the likelihood of being bound within a wide dynamic range ( Figure 3 E). This impact of the flanking nucleotides varies between NGN2 and MyoD1, further accounting for their differences in initial genomic binding. Interestingly, the influence of the flanking nucleotides depends on the central bases, hinting at a potential crosstalk for binding preference ( Figure 3 F). Although binding occurs more frequently in open chromatin, many accessible sites remain unbound ( Figures 2 A–2C). What, then, allows the model to accurately predict binding at these accessible sites beyond variation in the motif sequence? Intrigued by single-locus inspections ( Figures 3 D and S3 E), we hypothesized that nucleosome positioning could be a contributing feature, which was previously shown to influence binding. 43 The actual nucleosome phasing within open-chromatin regions, as determined with our existing micrococcal nuclease (MNase) sequencing measurements in mESCs, 44 indeed differs between sites that will or will not be bound ( Figure 3 G). Motifs, less likely to be bound by NGN2, tend to overlap with a nucleosome, whereas sites bound upon induction are more likely to reside between nucleosomes. As these sites lie within accessible regions, we presume that this preexisting phasing results from binding of other TFs, 45 , 46 and that the DNase I signal informs on it. 47 If correct, this should also become evident when specifically analyzing nucleosomes with known strong phasing, such as those surrounding sites bound by the TF CTCF. 48 , 49 , 50 , 51 Here, strong E-boxes for both NGN2 and MyoD1 indeed showed a higher frequency of binding if located in linkers, which is anticorrelated to the phased nucleosomes ( Figure S3 F). This suggests a binding hindrance of E-boxes by phased nucleosomes, which is in line with the observation that bHLH proteins do not bind to the nucleosome core in vitro . 43 Within less-accessible regions, the CNN model discerns a motif syntax of two E-box motifs, in line with higher motif occurrences, and provides further insights into their relative position ( Figures 2 E, 2F, S3 H, and S3 D), hinting to a potential synergy between motifs. To test this, we predicted the cooperativity of two motifs as a function of their distance, using in-silico -generated sequences. 33 This revealed a wide range of impact, with higher cooperativity between two motifs that reside close to each other ( Figure S3 G). Comparing this prediction with the measured binding preferences confirmed that shorter distances are enriched for binding at less-accessible regions ( Figures S3 H and S3I). Interestingly, within proximal motifs, the exact spacing matters. Inter-motif distances shorter than 9 bp did not enhance binding potential, possibly due to a molecular clash. The highest cooperativity was predicted at a 10–12-bp distance, corresponding to one helical turn of the DNA, whereas 15 bp, corresponding to an opposite facing on the DNA helix, was less favorable ( Figure S3 G). Actual binding measurements confirm this prediction, revealing a similar preference for shorter distances within 40 bp up to 100 bp. This correlates with the range of accessibility generated by the TFs, 52 their highest binding at 11 bp ( Figures 3 I and S3 J) (AlphaFold3 model 53 ) and the range of direct protein interactions. 54 It argues that spacing between motifs indeed impacts binding potential, a feature critical at sites of lower initial accessibility and presumably needed to counteract the chromatin barrier. Taken together a motif syntax composed of motif variants, their local frequency and the underlying chromatin state accounts for the ability of a genomic region to be bound by the tested TFs. Motif positions relative to phased nucleosomes further influence this likelihood within open chromatin, while at less-accessible regions, higher motif number with optimal inter-motif spacing is critical for binding ( Figure S3 K). These features form the basis of the successful predictions by the CNN model, which enables the contribution calculation of each feature both individually and in combination. The abilities of NGN2 and MyoD1 to open chromatin and activate genes differ depending on motif variant Following initial binding, we asked how NGN2 and MyoD1 subsequently impact chromatin and transcriptional activity by performing transposase-accessible chromatin sequencing (ATAC-seq) and ChIP-seq for lysine 27 acetylation of histone H3 (H3K27ac), and RNA polymerase II (RNA Pol II) 6 h after induction. For visualization, we employed dimensionality reduction of relevant genomic regions, that are either NGN2 or MyoD1 bound or show changes in accessibility at any time point ( Figure 4 A). This positioned the genomic regions in an intuitive way, allowing inspection of shared regions versus those exclusive for NGN2 or MyoD1. Figure 4 Motif variant-specific chromatin and transcription responses (A) Uniform manifold approximation and projection (UMAP) of relevant genomic regions (represented as single points, positioned based on similarities in accessibility and TF binding) visualizing initial accessibility, TF ChIP-seq and fold-changes in ATAC-seq, H3K27ac, and RNA Pol II ChIP-seq, colored from blue to red. Bound regions with low initial accessibility or factor-specific binding are outlined with dashed lines. Curved lines highlight NGN2-specific (green), MyoD1-specific (purple), and overlapping (brown) binding. The changes highlight increased activity in closed-bound sites, though with variable degrees (e.g., for NGN2 factor-specific sites, binding strength is graded from left to right and chromatin opening from top to bottom). (B) Example genomic locus, showing regions with similar 0 h accessibility and 6 h NGN2 binding, yet gaining different degrees of activity. (C) Contrasting the binding and activity on the motif variants using CNN model predictions on synthetic sequences. Predicted 6 h binding, change in ATAC-seq and H3K27ac ChIP-seq upon NGN2 induction at NGN2 E-box motifs with TA, GA, and GC central nucleotides across all accessibility-ranges are shown as heatmap from blue to red. The outlined box highlights the differences between the binding strength and its impact on chromatin for CAGATG versus CATATG motifs (at DHS 0.3, representing low initial accessibility with high dynamic range for gain of activity upon binding). (F) A library of barcoded transcriptional reporters, inserted stably in a defined locus, designed to report the effect of NGN2 motif variations on gene expression upon NGN2 induction. GA: single GA motif, GA + 40 + GA: two GA motifs with 40 bp between them. GA + 20 + GA: two GA motifs with 20 bp between them. GA + GA + GA: three GA motifs. GA + NN: one GA motif and another motif with the indicated central nucleotide and 3′-flanking nucleotides. Values correspond to differences in gene expression between respective construct relative to a scrambled motif control at the same time point post NGN2 induction ( Figure S4 H; Table S5 ). In (C)–(F), central nucleotides in blue, 5′-flanking in red, 3′-flanking in green. At 6 h, NGN2- or MyoD1-bound sites that are initially closed displayed an overall increase in accessibility, H3K27ac, and RNA Pol II enrichment ( Figure 4 A), suggesting that both TFs primarily activate chromatin upon binding. 55 Intriguingly, these activities varied among regions hinting at a differential impact ( Figure 4 B). To investigate this further, we trained a CNN model on ATAC-seq changes, which identified the impact of initial accessibility and the occurrence of cognate motifs. While the binding potential in accessible chromatin was higher ( Figure 4 A), opening was primarily observed at sites with initial lower accessibility, as might be expected ( Figure 4 C). Similar to the binding potential, opening potential differed between motif variants but, surprisingly, not always in the same order as the strength of binding ( Figures 4 C–4E and S4 A–S4F). For instance, while the CATATG motif had a higher binding potential, the CAGATG motif demonstrated a higher chromatin-opening potential ( Figures 4 C and S4 A–S4C). Also, flanking bases of the same motif variant exhibited different binding versus opening potentials, exemplified by comparing GT versus TT 3′-flanks of the CAGATG motif ( Figures 4 D, S4 D, S4E, and S4G). Such differences were also observed for MyoD1 at its cognate motifs ( Figure 4 E). To readily test whether these subtle single-base variations impact transcriptional output, we measured gene expression of over 20 barcoded reporter constructs, harboring different motif variations, inserted into the same genomic locus 23 , 56 ( Figures 4 F and S4 H). The resulting readout validated the expected increase of transcriptional output with higher motif density, but also that the slight motif variations can differentially impact gene expression, even when embedded in identical DNA sequence context (e.g., G-flanked CAGATG motif had the highest activity). This was in line with the enrichment of particular motif variants at NGN2 bound sites that are linked to the upregulated neurogenesis specific genes ( Figures S4 I and S4J). Altogether, these results argue that subtle sequence differences have direct functional impact on chromatin and gene expression. Since these do not always correlate with the measured binding strength, we hypothesized that they could reflect binding by different TF complexes. Single-base motif variations drive regulatory diversity via distinct TF combinations Many TFs can potentially engage with E-box motifs, such as bHLH and zinc-finger TF families. 4 , 57 , 58 To probe which TFs might be interacting with the motif variants preferred by NGN2 in our cellular system, we performed mass spectrometry from nuclear extracts from NGN2-induced cells using double stranded 20-bp DNA oligomers containing a single E-box motif as baits ( Figures S5 A and S5B). This detected multiple TFs including known E-box binders, such as TCF proteins, MGA, MAX, and TFAP4. Since dimerization is essential for bHLH-domain-containing factors to interact with an E-box, 3 , 59 we asked whether these proteins might heterodimerize with NGN2 or MyoD1. Immunoprecipitation followed by mass spectrometry identified TCF3 (TFE2/E2A), TCF4 (ITF2/SEF2), and TCF12 (HEB/HTF4) as potential protein partners for both TFs ( Figures 5 A, S5 C, and S5D). We hypothesized that the resulting dimers might have differential motif preferences, which we next tested in vitro by incubating various TF-pairs with purified genomic DNA and measuring binding by DNA affinity purification sequencing (DAP-seq). 60 Specifically, we generated DAP-seq profiles for NGN2, MyoD1, TCF3E12, TCF3E47, TCF4, and TCF12 in all potential TF-dimer-pairs ( Figure 5 B). This identified combination-specific enrichment profiles, clustering consistently for all 20 TF-pairs ( Figure S5 E). While E-box motifs were enriched among all pairs, this further uncovered differential enrichments for motif variants, suggesting dimer-specific binding preferences ( Figure 5 C). For example, the CATATG motif was preferentially bound by the NGN2 homodimer, whereas the NGN2-TCF3E12 heterodimer showed preference for the CAGATG motif, in line with the observation that binding versus opening potentials of these motifs vary. Similarly, TCF homodimers preferred motifs starting with G flanks, whereas TCF-MyoD1 combinations preferred A. This supports our earlier observation that NGN2 and MyoD1 binding preferences depend on both central and flanking bases, with the influence of the flanks varying according to the central bases ( Figure 3 F). It further suggests that these preferences are driven by distinct sets of protein partners. Scale bar, 50 μm. To test this hypothesis experimentally in the cellular context, we tagged the Tcf3 allele and profiled its genomic binding in mESCs, which showed similar motif preferences to TCF homodimers ( Figures S5 G and S5H). Subsequently, we decreased levels of TCF3, TCF4, or TCF12 prior to NGN2 induction and measured the impact on NGN2 binding ( Figures 5 D and S5 I). Knockdown of TCFs reduced NGN2 binding specifically at the CAGATG motif, which is preferentially bound by the TCF-NGN2 heterodimers in vitro . However, it did not reduce NGN2 binding at the CATATG motif, which is preferentially bound by the NGN2 homodimer in vitro . In line with the in vitro binding, the effect differed depending on which TCF was reduced, whereby TCF3 had the highest impact on the CAGATGG motif, which is the most enriched motif for the NGN2-induced neurogenic trajectory ( Figure S4 J). Decreasing cellular TCF3 levels caused failure of NGN2-induced neurogenesis, further suggesting that their dimerization is required for differentiation ( Figures 5 E and S5 J). Importantly, the observations on the initial binding strength and chromatin opening were in general correlated with the motif preferences of the TF-pairs ( Figures 4 C, 4D, and S5 F). Together, this demonstrates that different activities at motif variants reflect binding by different sets of protein partners for both NGN2 and MyoD1 ( Figures S5 I–S5M), whereby single base differences account for significant regulatory diversity. Newly activated TFs reshape the accessibility landscape, causing further divergence in NGN2- and MyoD1-binding patterns While NGN2 and MyoD1 binding is initially guided by chromatin, their binding subsequently modifies chromatin ( Figures 2 , 3 , and 4 ). To investigate the impact of this change, we profiled binding and chromatin features at later time points. In addition to their factor-specific binding at closed regions, both NGN2 and MyoD1 gained additional binding sites at 24 h. These are characterized by lower accessibility at earlier time points yet become more accessible at 24 h ( Figures 6 A, 6B, S6 A, and S6B). These new sites are specific to each factor, reflecting further divergence of genomic binding reducing the overlap between MyoD1-bound and NGN2-bound sites. Contrasting the binding between 6 and 24 h ( Figures 6 C, S6 C, and S6D) revealed a shift in enriched E-box motif variants and presence of several other TF motifs beyond NGN2 and MyoD1. For both factors, motifs specific to 6 h were associated with the pluripotent cell state, coinciding with motifs for ESRRB and POU(OCT)/SOX. At 24 h, however, EBF and ONECUT motifs are enriched at newly formed NGN2 sites and MEF2 and PITX/OTX motifs at newly formed MyoD1 sites. TFs, corresponding to these motifs, such as Ebf2 and Ebf3, exhibited correlated changes in their gene expression ( Figures 6 C, 6D, S6 E, and S6J). Contrasting nuclear protein abundance between mESCs and NGN2 24 h induction confirmed increased levels of EBF2/3, as well as a decrease in pluripotency-related TFs ( Figure S6 F). To address how EBF2/3 affects NGN2-binding patterns, we compared the accessibility profiles of newly opened EBF sites that are either co-bound by NGN2 or remain unbound. Comparison of these genomic regions showed NGN2 binding and increased chromatin opening if there is an NGN2 motif within a 100-bp distance around the EBF motif, and thus at a distance shorter than a nucleosomal repeat length. This is readily supported by the impact upon decreasing EBF2/3 levels ( Figures 6 E, 6F, S6 G, and S6H). Modeling CNNs for 24 h NGN2- and MyoD1-induced accessibility changes identified EBF and MEF/PBX motifs as chromatin-opening features. The gained binding occurred within the immediate range of accessibility created by these TFs, with factor-specific spacing restrictions ( Figures S6 I–S6M). This predicts that the motif syntax, composed of individual motif sequences and their relative positions, impacts these TFs’ activity on chromatin. We conclude that NGN2 and MyoD1 engagement to initially closed sites at 6 h activates expression of other TFs. These TFs subsequently change the chromatin landscape, creating accessibility that generates new opportunities for binding by NGN2 and MyoD1, further diverging the activity patterns in a lineage-specific fashion ( Figure 6 G). The CNN-derived, chromatin-dependent motif syntax is transferable and predicts TF-chromatin interactions in different cellular contexts Since the observed binding patterns for NGN2 and MyoD1 are dependent on the initial genomic accessibility, which itself reflects the activity of other TFs, we expect them to vary between cell types. If our predictive model for binding is generalizable, it should be transferable to different cell types as long as their starting accessibility is taken into account. We tested this hypothesis using available ChIP-seq and ATAC-seq datasets from a widely used myogenesis model, C2C12 cells, where MyoD1 can be induced by changing culture conditions, comparable to our dox-induction system ( Figures S7 A and S7B). 61 , 62 , 63 Analyzing MyoD1 binding in this system identifies the same preferred binding motifs as in our cellular system; however, the actual sites of MyoD1 binding in C2C12 cells were largely different from mESCs, with only 12.5% overlap among consensus binding sites ( Figures 7 A–7C, S7 C, and S7D). Differentially bound regions indeed had high accessibility in only one of the cell types, whereas overlapping regions had varying degrees of starting accessibility. Despite the low similarity in genomic binding between the two cell types, the CNN model, trained only on the binding landscape in mESCs, accurately predicts the binding in C2C12 cells by only incorporating their accessibility prior to induction. The model performs comparably to its performance in mESCs ( Figures 7 D, S3 A, S7 E, and S7F), demonstrating that the rules of MyoD1 binding learned in mESC can readily be transferred to other cell states with their unique accessibility landscapes. These findings illustrate that chromatin binding can readily be explained by preexisting DNA accessibility and a composite motif syntax, which, in case of MyoD1 and NGN2, highlights distinct sequence specificities. Next, we applied our framework to a highly studied bHLH TF, Ascl1, for which, however, varying motif preferences, 17 , 58 , 64 , 65 and chromatin-binding characteristics 6 , 66 , 67 , 68 have been reported. Upon induction in mESCs, we observed Ascl1 binding to a motif distinct from that of NGN2 or MyoD1, consistent with its in vitro DAP-seq binding when dimerized with TCFs ( Figures S8 A–S8E). Next, we used the same approach to determine binding of NGN3, a close paralog expected to have similar DNA sequence specificity as NGN2. NGN3 is expressed in the pancreas and required for generating insulin-producing cells. 69 , 70 When expressed in mESCs, we found NGN3 binding to be highly similar to that of NGN2, leading to neuronal differentiation ( Figures S8 A, S8B, S8F, and S8G), demonstrating that our approach of utilizing a combined model of preferred DNA sequence and preexisting accessibility can be more broadly applied to other TFs of this family. At sites where NGN2 or MyoD1 open chromatin, our model predicts a motif syntax that is largely independent on existing accessibility. Therefore, genomic sequences bearing such syntax are expected to be bound in all cell types where the respective TF is expressed. To test this hypothesis, we analyzed a large set of cis -regulatory elements (cCREs) identified within the ENCODE consortium 71 and used the model to predict binding for a range of different DNA accessibility values for each region ( Figures 7 E and S7 G). Top ranking regions that provide high NGN2-binding potential at low accessibility indeed show accessibility in tissues (i.e., brain and cerebellum) where NGN2 is expressed. These regions included cCREs of genes known to be critical for neuronal differentiation, which we also observed as being activated during the induced differentiation of mESCs, arguing for a developmentally conserved feature. A comparable analysis applied to MyoD1 revealed its activity in muscle, but also its less well-known activity in thymus development ( Figure S7 G). 72 , 73 Given its high predictive power, we wondered whether the CNN model could assist in interpreting sequence variants previously linked to gene expression variation as expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) 74 within genome-wide association studies (GWASs). To test this, we predicted binding of NGN2 at SNPs that modify an NGN2 motif variant ( Figure 7 E). This is exemplified by the variant rs58130172 (GWAS: GCST90105038 75 ) at the DISP3 locus, a gene reported to influence neural fate decisions in a dose-sensitive manner 76 ( Figure 7 F). While the predictions on the reference enhancer sequence foresee low binding with no activation potential, the alternative sequence with the SNP predicts stronger binding and activation. This variant had indeed been identified as an eQTL, and the alternative allele showed increased DISP3 expression in the brain ( Figure 7 G). Taken together, the identified chromatin- and sequence-dependent motif syntax is transferrable to other contexts, providing predictive power and deepening our understanding of how TFs that recognize such short and abundant motifs achieve specific regulatory outcomes and drive cellular differentiation. Discussion Our findings illustrate how distinct DNA sequence syntax, chromatin accessibility, and interaction partners underlie both shared and TF-specific binding of two distinct lineage-driving TFs, NGN2, and MyoD1, despite their preference for seemingly similar low-complexity motifs. Building on previous studies that linked TF binding with chromatin features, 77 , 78 our approach isolates primary TF binding from context-specific confounding factors, identifies features determining opportunistic, cooperative, or pioneer binding and provides several orthologous assays, testing and ultimately validating predictions experimentally. Leveraging recent advances in deep learning for de novo motif discovery 79 , 80 and integrating relevant, traceable preexisting chromatin features, we identify a TF-specific syntax predictive of primary TF binding across cellular contexts that we validate in vitro and in vivo . Consistent with prior observations and similar to most eukaryotic TFs, both NGN2 and MyoD1 preferentially bind regions of open chromatin but still depend on the presence of E-box motifs. Many such sites are shared between both TFs, reflecting their opportunistic binding to open chromatin, which is determined by a cell-type-specific accessibility landscape. Notably, many motifs residing in open chromatin remain unbound, yet binding can still be accurately predicted by the model, likely reflecting local nucleosome positioning. 47 This restricted access in open chromatin in vivo supports the in vitro observation that bHLH TFs prefer motifs that are not embedded within the core nucleosome. 43 This may also explain the variable but limited distance observed in opportunistic TF binding adjacent to other TFs. During lineage progression, newly expressed TFs promote chromatin opening, 81 creating additional binding opportunities for NGN2 and MyoD1. Given the lineage-specific nature of these cooperating TFs, the resulting sites likely contribute directly to differentiation rather than being passive consequences of chromatin change. This combinatorial model accounts for cell-type specificity of many chromatin-sensitive TFs and the diverse developmental roles of the Neurogenin/Neurod/Onecut axis in neural, pancreatic, and intestinal development, similarly to those of MyoD1/Myogenin/Mef2 in muscle and thymus development. 73 , 82 In contrast to this opportunistic and chromatin-sensitive binding, NGN2 and MyoD1 can bind and open initially inaccessible regions at specific sites, acting as “pioneer factors.” These rare events are confined to complex and similarly rare composite motifs enriched for TF-specific variants, helping reconcile conflicting reports on their chromatin sensitivity. 83 Rather than a binary model of TF activity as “pioneer” or “settler,” our data support a locus-specific model of chromatin sensitivity. Rare composite sites are consistently targeted across relevant cell types, such as MyoD1 in C2C12 cells and NGN2 in brain, and many are linked to known lineage-driving targets (e.g., Neurod, Onecut, and Ebf). CNN-based modeling further reveals that binding potential of motif variants differs from their activation potential, indicating that subtle motif variation modulate output. We experimentally link these effects to bHLH homo- and heterodimer preferences, which validates by TF depletion. Such differential activation upon closed chromatin binding likely reflects distinct cofactor recruitment by specific bHLH partners. Over differentiation time, regulation at these motif variants further evolves, correlating with downstream expression of other E-box-binding TFs (e.g., NEUROD1, 84 ZEB2, 85 ZBTB18, 86 , 87 and MYOGENIN 88 ), underscoring how minimal motif variation, amplified by protein interactions, drives functional specificity and dynamic gene regulation. These findings identify and can potentially account for a broad spectrum of chromatin sensitivity of individual TFs, spanning opportunistic binding at low-complexity motifs and deterministic binding at rare composite motifs that shape lineage-driving programs. Despite this complexity, we define a roadmap for decoding and experimentally testing primary TF-binding behavior and regulatory impact supported by predictive models. 89 , 90 , 91 Informed by chromatin state, sequence features and factor presence, these models can predict future TF binding during cellular differentiation, providing tools both for guiding cellular engineering 92 , 93 and for deciphering the regulatory impact of sequence variants. 94 , 95 , 96 Limitations of the study While the inducible expression system in mESCs is effective and controllable, it has limitations in assessing the effects of potential variability in TF levels and the influence of other interaction partners present in different cell types. Furthermore, predicting the downstream changes after primary TF action remains challenging, as it requires accurately linking activity in regulatory elements to their target genes.
